title: Drug mega-trial set to lift curtain on European trafficking
summary: The drug trafficking trial held in Brussels from Monday, with 125 defendants of 15 different nationalities and a reinforced concrete bunker courthouse, is expected to last up to five months.

title: France's interior minister weakened by political crisis over immigration bill
summary: Gérald Darmanin and the prime minister have to break the deadlock following the Assemblée Nationale's rejection of the government's controversial bill.

title: More than 100 dead in northwest China earthquake
summary: The deadly quake caused significant damage on Monday evening, including collapsed houses, and sent people running into the street for safety, state news agency Xinhua said.

title: US announces 10-nation coalition to combat Huthi attacks in Red Sea
summary: Washington announced Tuesday the creation of a new force to protect ships that have come under attack by drones and ballistic missiles fired from Houthi-controlled areas of Yemen. The coalition includes the US, UK, Bahrain, Canada, France, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Seychelles and Spain.

title: The risk of instability is dangerously increasing in the Middle East
summary: Yemeni rebels have begun to disrupt shipping in the Red Sea in solidarity with the Palestinian Islamist movement. Containing the Houthi threat is a formidable challenge.

title: Ultra-Orthodox Jews join Israeli army to defend their country
summary: Since the October 7 attacks in Israel, hundreds of Haredi Jews – traditionally opposed to the army – have voluntarily joined up, despite their religious convictions.

title: Explosion and fire at Guinea fuel depot kills 14 and injures 190
summary: The incident happened on Monday at the state oil company's main depot in the Kaloum district of Conakry, near the port. The explosion brought the city to a standstill.

title: Pope Francis gives green light to blessings for same-sex couples
summary: Same-sex couples can now receive blessings from priests – as long as the ritual is not confused with the sacrament of marriage, which in the Catholic Church can only take place between a man and a woman.

title: BP suspends Red Sea shipping transits after attacks
summary: In the past few days, four of the five world's largest container shipping companies have paused or rerouted movements through the Red Sea.

title: Bangladesh's prime minister has plunged her country into authoritarianism
summary: Sheikh Hasina has unleashed a full-scale crackdown on her opponents in the run-up to the January legislative elections. Since July, 20,000 activists have been arrested and 88,000 others are facing legal action.

title: EU opens 'illegal content' probe into Elon Musk's X
summary: The EU launched proceedings on Monday after identifying disinformation related to Hamas's October 7 attack in Israel.

title: El-Sissi wins third term as Egypt's president
summary: Abdel Fattah El-Sissi won an overwhelming majority of votes to continue leading as president. The win means he will be in power until 2029, after which he won't be allowed to run again.

title: The final verses of Gaza's poet Refaat Alareer
summary: Gazan intellectuals have been mourning the death of Refaat Alareer, professor of English literature and emblematic voice of Gaza, killed on December 6 during an Israeli bombardment.

title: French prosecutors seek life sentence for ex-wife of serial killer
summary: Monique Olivier is accused of involvement in the murders of two young women by her then-husband Michel Fourniret. She is already serving a life sentence for complicity in other murders committed by her husband.

title:
Germany's AfD party wins first city
mayoral election in symbolic victory for far-right
summary: Alternative for Germany candidate Tim Lochner was elected mayor of Pirna on Sunday, a symbolic victory for the far-right party. The question of a possible ban on the movement is entering public debate.

title: Guyana rekindles the world's thirst for oil
summary: Between 2020 and 2023, Guyanese oil production increased fivefold. The Latin American country with a population of 800,000 currently ranks 31st among oil-producing nations but could move up to 18th place by 2027.

title: French Foreign Affairs Ministry official killed by Israeli bombardment in Gaza
summary: Ahmed Abu Shamla, an employee of the Gaza consular office for over 20 years, died on Saturday. Part of his family had been evacuated from Gaza, but he had chosen to stay with his adult children.

title: Record rainfall helps recharge France's water tables
summary: A December 14 report from the French Geological and Mining Research Bureau found that the situation was 'improving considerably.'

title: Paris barge owners still don't know what to expect for 2024 Olympics
summary: Despite the presentation of safety and traffic plans at the end of November, operators of floating restaurants, bars and nightclubs on the Seine are still unsure about the conditions under which they will be able to operate during the Olympic events.

title: In India, the opposition is being steamrolled by Narendra Modi's party
summary: With just a few months to go before the spring 2024 general elections, Rahul Gandhi's Congress Party will have to make a considerable effort to take on the almighty prime minister's Indian People's Party.

title: The mystery of morning sickness finally solved
summary: A consortium of international researchers has uncovered the workings of a hormone involved in this symptom, opening the way to treatment for pregnant women affected by hyperemesis gravidarum.

title: The 'wazalendo,' 'patriots' at war in eastern DRC
summary: These militiamen are ready to fight the M23 rebels alongside the Congolese army and support the re-election of Félix Tshisekedi.

title: On board the Paris-Berlin night train: Is the European sleeper reawakening?
summary: The return of the nighttime service after a nine-year hiatus is part of a global drive to revive sleeper trains to reduce the environmental impact of travel.

title: Neo-Nazi leaflets in southern France spark outrage and indifference
summary: In the small town of Quissac, the Republican rally launched by radical left MP Michel Sala after anti-Semitic and homophobic flyers were discovered in letterboxes in late November, failed to rally residents in numbers.

title: 'Flantophilia,' or how eating a flan can become an 'absolute pleasure'
summary: Forget the bland industrial dessert with its artificial flavors, colorings, gelling agents and modified starch. Instead, search for the quintessence of this pastry speciality, a simple treasure whose success is rooted in childhood.

title: Iceland volcano erupts after weeks of earthquakes
summary: Ahead of what the prime minister described as a 'considerable eruption', authorities had evacuated the nearly 4,000 inhabitants of the fishing town of Grindavik.

title: Jonathan Majors dropped by Marvel after assault conviction
summary: Best known as Kang the Conqueror, the rising star was found guilty on Monday of assaulting and harassing his former girlfriend.

title: Texas governor signs bill that lets police arrest migrants who illegally cross US border
summary: Taking effect in March, the new law allows any Texas law enforcement officer to arrest anyone suspected of entering the country illegally. As many as 12,000 immigrants per day cross the US southern border, overwhelming immigration authorities.

title: After Hamas attack, residents of Kfar Aza kibbutz now mourn their dead killed by Israeli army
summary: The community was particularly hard hit by the Hamas attack on October 7, and two of its members, who were taken hostage in Gaza, have just been killed by Israeli soldiers.

title: Gifts, travel, trees: What's the carbon footprint of the holidays?
summary: Explore the carbon footprint of Christmas and New Year celebrations in French households with Le Monde's graphs of the main greenhouse gas emissions associated with the holidays.

title: The second passing of 1980s design pioneer Terence Conran
summary: The closure of The Conran Shop in Paris marks the end of the legacy of the British father of consumer design, who died in 2020.

title: 'Take this pill, it'll help you steal and you'll have money:' The child trafficking web behind the petty thieves of Paris' Trocadéro
summary: The trial of six Algerians accused of plying dozens of unaccompanied Moroccan minors with psychotropic drugs, in order to coerce them into robbing passers-by, opened in Paris on December 14.
